column1: Milwaukie  is a city mostly in Clackamas County
column3: United States; a very small portion of the city extends into Multnomah County. The population was 20
column4: 291 at the 2010 census. Founded in 1847 on the banks of the Willamette River
column6: known as the Dogwood City of the West
column7: was incorporated in 1903 and is the birthplace of the Bing cherry. The city is now a suburb of Portland and also adjoins the unincorporated areas of Clackamas and Oak Grove.

column1: Milwaukie was settled in 1847 and formally platted in 1849 as a rival to the upriver Oregon City by Lot Whitcomb
column3: Wisconsin. At the time
column4: the Wisconsin city was also frequently spelled "Milwaukie" before the current spelling was adopted. Some accounts also state that the Oregon city used an alternate spelling to prevent confusion at the post office.Whitcomb arrived in Oregon in 1848 and settled on a donation land claim
column5: where he built a sawmill and a gristmill. Milwaukie rivaled Portland and Oregon City for a time
column6: but Portland eventually became the bigger city because it had a deeper port. The first post office at Milwaukie was established in 1850
column7: with Whitcomb as the first postmaster. The community was incorporated by the Oregon Legislative Assembly on February 4
column9: originally as the Town of Milwaukie.The Oregon and California Railroad named their station there Milwaukee in 1870 and corrected it to Milwaukie in 1892. As the city center grew further from the railroad and a branch line was built across the Willamette to Oswego
column10: Milwaukie station was replaced and renamed Lambert for Joseph H. Lambert
column11: a pioneer orchardist who developed the Lambert cherry. The name of the station was changed to East Milwaukee in 1913 and corrected to East Milwaukie in 1916.The Bing cherry
column13: was developed in Milwaukie by another pioneer orchardist
column15: who settled in the area with his brother Henderson Luelling.

column2: the downtown area of Milwaukie is undergoing a revival in which new apartments and retail space are under construction and a riverfront park is being developed.

column1: Milwaukie is the home of Dark Horse Comics. Dark Horse is known for publishing works including Sin City
column3: and the original graphic novel series 300
column4: as well for producing dozens of films and television series
column6: based on characters created by Dark Horse founder Mike Richardson. The total office space of Dark Horse Comics occupies three of the city blocks in downtown Milwaukie
column7: sporting numerous display windows visible to transit riders.Bob's Red Mill is located here and employs a few hundred people.

column1: From 2015-2016 Milwaukie saw a boom in real estate. It was named the ninth hottest real estate market in 2016 by realtor.com. A big draw to the city was noticed right after the Orange-line from TriMet finished in 2015. A 1.4 billion dollar project connecting the close-in suburb right to the heart of downtown Portland. A year into the new Orange-line
column2: pricing for homes raised up 12.2% and city officials said there are zero vacancies for retail storefronts in Milwaukie's downtown area. In addition to the new Orange-line
column3: Milwaukie finished a 2.2 million dollar project to the cites waterfront park. The city had a grand opening on May 1

column1: Milwaukie is served by the North Clackamas School District and most children attend one of ten public elementary schools
column3: Rex Putnam High School
column5: and New Urban High School. Since 1996
column6: Milwaukie High School has annually hosted the nationally recognized Living History Day. On this day thousands of veterans are welcomed into the school to help educate students about the past.

column1: There is also a private Catholic high school
column3: named after St. Jean-Baptiste de la Salle

column1: The city is home to the Ledding Library
column2: a public library that is part of the Library Information Network of Clackamas County.

column1: The city has one college Clackamas Community College Harmony.
Milwaukie is within the TriMet transit district and is served by several TriMet bus lines.  TriMet established a transit center in downtown Milwaukie in 1981
column2: served by as many as 12 routes (in 2000)
column3: using on-street stops around the intersection of Jackson Street and 21st Avenue
column4: next to Milwaukie City Hall. Since 2010
column5: the bus stops that previously comprised Milwaukie TC are no longer designated as a "transit center" by TriMet. In fall 2015
column6: the focal point for rider transfers between routes shifted southward from the former transit-center location
column7: with the opening of a new light rail station at the south end of downtown.

column1: TriMet's MAX Light Rail service was extended to Milwaukie on September 12
column2: 2015. Construction of the MAX Orange Line
column3: a light-rail connection between Portland and Milwaukie
column4: began in 2011. Although this project was planned for many years
column5: it faced strong opposition by opponents of "Portland Creep"; in September 2012
column6: opponents succeeded in passing a ballot initiative requiring that all Clackamas County spending on light rail be directly approved by the voters. The 7.3-mile (11.7 km) line was sufficiently complete by May 15
column8: for 500 passengers to make an initial special run along its whole length. Regular passenger service began four months later.

column1: Streetcars began serving Milwaukie in August 1892
column2: when the East Side Railway Company extended its service beyond the then-town of Sellwood.  The company built a carbarn and workshop in downtown Milwaukie
column3: on Jackson Street at River Road (now McLoughlin Blvd. at that location)
column4: which opened in December 1892.  The following year
column5: the company extended its line to Oregon City
column6: and interurban service between Portland and Oregon City via Milwaukie began operating.  During the several decades after 1900
column7: a succession of other private companies
column10: operated the streetcar and interurban service to and through the town.  All interurban service was discontinued in January 1958. At the time
column11: the Portland–Milwaukie–Oregon City and Portland–Sellwood–Bellrose lines had been the last streetcar or interurban service operating in the Portland metropolitan area
column12: and not until 1986 did interurban service return—in the form of MAX (light rail) between Portland and Gresham.  Oregon Motor Stages
column14: had provided some bus service through Milwaukie until 1954
column15: when it abruptly ceased all operation. Replacement transit-bus service was introduced in 1955 by Intercity Buses
column17: a member of a consortium of four bus companies collectively known as the "Blue Bus" lines
column18: and Intercity expanded its service after the 1958 abandonment of the rail service.  TriMet
column19: a new government-owned public transit authority
column21: and in September 1970 it took over all of the "Blue Bus" companies.  TriMet has been the primary provider of transit service in Milwaukie since that time.

column1: Amtrak passenger trains pass through Milwaukie without stopping. However
column2: for a brief period in the early 1980s an experimental Amtrak service named the Willamette Valley Express made a regular stop in Milwaukie
column3: just east of the intersection of Harrison Street and Highway 224 (a location Amtrak referred to as East Milwaukie).  The service
column4: which ran twice a day in each direction and connected Portland with Eugene
column5: was introduced on a trial basis in August 1980 and discontinued at the end of 1981.
